narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project 'req_8f03ec1fc5' expects to generate a significant amount of multi-modal datasets from youth participants, including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging and/or physiological measures, derived variables, and associated documentation such as protocols, data dictionary, and README files. The estimated volume of these datasets will be substantial, with the largest portion attributed to neurobiological data.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project will be preserved and shared through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), following the guidelines set forth by the NIH. This decision is based on the importance of facilitating open science, promoting collaboration among researchers, and enhancing the reproducibility of findings in the field of autism and social communication research. By sharing these data, we aim to contribute to a comprehensive understanding of neurodevelopmental profiles in youth with autism compared to typically developing peers.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
Study protocols detailing participant recruitment, assessment procedures, and data collection methods.
Data collection instruments used for behavioral, cognitive, and clinical assessments.
A comprehensive data dictionary explaining variable definitions, measurement scales, and any data transformations applied.
README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, content, and instructions for use.
NDA GUID elements collected for each participant to ensure harmonization with existing datasets within the NDA.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code will be necessary to access or manipulate shared scientific data. Specifically, neuroimaging data may require the use of software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages) for analysis. Additionally, statistical analyses and data manipulation may involve programming languages like R or Python, utilizing libraries such as pandas, NumPy, and SciPy for data handling and computations. Access to these tools can be obtained through their respective official websites or repositories.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. The project will adhere to the standards set by the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) for formatting and structuring data submissions, including the use of standardized vocabularies and ontologies where applicable. For neuroimaging data, standards such as the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) will be applied to ensure consistency in data organization and description. These standards will facilitate the integration of our datasets with existing research data, promoting a more cohesive understanding of autism spectrum disorders.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that aligns with NIH guidelines for data sharing and management. The NDA provides a secure and accessible platform for storing, sharing, and analyzing research data related to mental health disorders.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: To ensure the scientific data are findable and identifiable, each dataset will be assigned a persistent unique identifier (DOI) upon submission to the NDA. Additionally, datasets will be indexed using standard metadata descriptors, allowing for efficient discovery through search functionalities provided by the NDA.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Once shared, the data will remain accessible for a minimum of 10 years following the initial release date, as per the NDA's data retention policies, ensuring long-term availability for research purposes.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, considerations related to informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections will affect the extent of data sharing. Specifically, data use limitations may apply to protect participant identities and maintain confidentiality, in accordance with the broad data sharing consent/assent obtained from participants.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain components of the scientific data may be controlled, requiring approval through the NDA's data access request system. This measure is particularly relevant for datasets containing sensitive or identifiable information, where additional oversight is necessary to ensure compliance with regulatory and ethical standards.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, several measures will be implemented:
De-identification of datasets to remove direct identifiers.
Use of Certificates of Confidentiality, where applicable, to further safeguard sensitive information.
Implementation of secure data transfer protocols when sharing data with collaborators or repositories.
Adherence to IRB-approved guidelines for data handling and sharing.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. Regular oversight will occur on a semi-annual basis, involving review of data submission statuses, compliance with sharing timelines, and adherence to privacy and confidentiality measures. The PI and designated research staff will be responsible for ensuring that all aspects of the plan are executed as outlined, with updates to the plan made as necessary to reflect changes in project activities or data management best practices.
